Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 21. Practicing Austerities
Now, King Shuddhodana sent out many scouts in the Bodhisattva's direction. From them he heard that the Bodhisattva did not have servants waiting on him and was wandering alone.
Manual - Tibetan (བོད་ཡིག།): དེ་ནས་ནགས་གཅིག་ཏུ། འཁོར་ལྔ་དྲུང་ན་ཡོད་ཅིང་། གཞན་མི་མང་པོ་ཞིག་ལྡོག་འགྲོ་བ་འབྲི། དེ་ནས་ཆུ་ཀླུང་ནེ་རཉྫ་ནའི་འགྲམ་མཐའ་ནགས་ཀྱི་སྐོར་བའི་ནེའུ་གསིང་གི་དབུས་ཤིང་དྲུང་གཅིག་ཏུ་དཀའ་ཐུབ་མཛད་པའི་རྣམ་པ་འབྲི་སྟེ། སྤྱི་ཁྱབ་དང་འདྲ། དཀའ་བ་རྣམ་པ་དྲུག་སྦྱོད་པའི་རིམ་པ་མང་པོ་ཡོད་ཀྱང་། དེ་ཙམ་གྱི་ཆོག་པ་འདུག ཕྱུག་རྫིས་སྙན་ལ་ཤིང་འཛུགས་པ་དང་། ལྷ་གསུམ་གྱི་གཏམ་རྗེས་སུ་སྒྲོག་པ་སོགས་ཀྱང་འབྲི།
Manual - English: In a forest, the Buddha dwells with the five disciples. Many other men leave the Buddha. Under a tree in a forest near the bank of the Nairañjanā (ne ranya+dza na), the Buddha lives an ascetic life. This is the same as in mainstream. There are actually six forms of ascetic practices, but what we have here is fine. Herders put sticks in the ears of the Buddha. Three gods spread the news.

Sun of Faith - English: So he sent three hundred servants, and King Suprabuddha sent another two hundred.
The Bodhisattva understood that if he were to wander in the forest with a retinue of five hundred, he would not attain the nectar of realization while surrounded by many people.
So he selected three from his father's side and two from his mother's, and sent the remaining people back.
Inscription - English: He sent everyone back but five from his mother and father.

Sun of Faith - English: Dressed as sages, he and these companions travelled south of the city of Gaya to the town of Uruvilva. On the banks of the Nairanjana River they saw a pleasant meadow exquisitely ringed by a thick forest and various kinds of trees.
"Here in this wilderness retreat I will stay and cultivate detachment," thought the Bodhisattva, and he sat beneath a tree.
Teeth touching teeth, tongue touching the roof of his mouth, his mind grasped his mind. While he held himself rigidly, a continuous stream of perperation emerged from his pores.

[At first,] through such ascetic practice, he experienced unbearably intense sensations. Even so, he undertook effort without relenting. He trained his body without inattention. He rested in awareness without mental dullness. And he rested his mind one-pointedly without distraction.

In the second period, he began to cultivate meditation on the decay of the body, and through training the rising and falling of his breath was suppressed, which brought all his vital winds to the crown of his head. An unbearable pain in his head arose, as if it were pierced by an iron spike. Yet he continued as before without relenting.
Scene working notes: These next austerities are an abreviation of a more numerous set described in the Vinayavastu.

Sun of Faith - English: In the third period, when he actually achieved meditation on the decay of the body, his vital winds were suppressed, and blew out his ears like the blowing of the blacksmith's bellows. He experienced unbearable pain, yet continued as before without relenting.

In the fourth period, when he achieved ultimate meditation on the decay of the body, he suppressed movement of the vital winds, and his belly became distended. He experiened pain in his head, like a sharp razor blade was cutting his body open from the inside, and like he was hanging over a fire pit. Yet still he continued as before without relenting.
In the fifth period, he ate only miniscule amounts, such as the broth of a boiled pea, bean, or grain of rice. As long as its vital energy did not not fade, he would not eat another.

At that time, the gods asked that he practice taking vital energy through the pores of his skin. The Bodhisattva thought, "For me to practice taking vital energy when I have given up food would be hypocritical, false, wrong, and deceiving of others." So he rejected the practice of taking vital energy.
His body became emaciated and weak but still he continued as before without relenting.

How weak did his body become? His body became like a totally withered and shrunken asita or magnolia stalk. His head became pocked like an old gourd. His eyballs receded into their sockets like stars in a well. His ribs became uneven. His backbone became like a braid of hair. When he wanted to get up, he fell forward and and when he wanted to sit, he fell back. So he needed to alternate between supporting and setting down his upper and lower body. The roots of his body hair had rotted, so that when he rubbed his body with his hands his hair fell to the ground.
Then his complexion, once bright, was dimmed. Three gods came there, and one said Gautama is dark!" Dark blue” said the second. “Maroon,” said the third.

At that three examples formed in the Bodhisattva’s mind. He thought, "Rub together sticks wet from sitting in water but they will not catch fire. Likewise, attachment to sense pleasures in body and mind cannot bring release. Wood that is only slightly wet is just the same. Likewise, freedom from desire for the body but not the mind will not bring release. But rub together dry sticks and fire ignites. Likewise, freedom from desire for body and mind makes it possible to know, to see, and to touch the things of the world."

In the sixth period he slept a little, laying down upon a seat of very coarse grass. He practiced as he had earlier, save that he at only a single sesame or other kind of seed. Until its nutrients had dissolved, he would not eat another seed. So his body became even weaker than before. In this way he practiced the austerity of taking very little food, and continued as before without relenting.

During this time King Suddhodana dispatched two hundred and fifty men each day to check on the Bodhisattva. The same were also sent from Devadaha. Each day, when the group carried news back, King Shuddhodana was overcome with intense sorrow.

The queen's retinue also slept on grass mats. Yashodhara gave away here jewelry and in that way engaged in ascetic practices. The king ordered, "Yashodhara is pregnant with a son and this situation will be harmful to him, so nobody speak of the austerities to Yashodhara. The messengers must not speak about the Bodhisattva's ascetic practices to anyone but me."
Even though the king was overcome with sorrow at the news he heard, he hid his feelings and deceived the queen's retinue with false accounts.

Then in the seventh period he thought, "These ascetic practices are not enough." He would eat what was referred to as the worst possible food: a tiny pill made from the urine and dung of an unweaned calf. He would not eat another until its nutrients had dissolved.
If he wanted to sleep a short while, we went to the cemetary, and used a decayig corpse as a cushion. Now his body was even more emaciated than before, as if his body dried up.
Inscription - English: Using a decaying corpse as a pillow.

Sun of Faith - English: Village boys and girls and cowherds approached him. They stuffed wool, flowers, and pebbles into his ears. They pushed a splinter of wood into his ears until it came out his nose, and into his nose until it came out his ears. They passed other such things back and forth between his ears and nose.
Inscription - English: Performing difficult austeries by the river.

Sun of Faith - English: One of them said, "Hey, look at the filthy monster!" They threw clods of earth and stones at his body but he did not seem to see or hear them. Yet he continued as before without relenting.
